content: Requirements for naturalization to citizenship through service in the Armed Forces of the United States. The period of required service for naturalization is reduced to 2 years. No fees can be charged for filing a petition for naturalization or issuing a certificate of naturalization. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to reduce the period of required service for naturalization to 2 years. No fees can be charged for filing a petition for naturalization or issuing a certificate of naturalization, except as required by state laws. Additionally, a new section is added for naturalization through enlistment in the Armed Forces with eligibility for access to classified information. Naturalization through enlistment in the armed forces of the United States with eligibility for access to classified information is now allowed under the amended Immigration and Nationality Act, reducing the required service period to 2 years. No fees can be charged for filing a petition for naturalization or issuing a certificate of naturalization, except as required by state laws. A person who served honorably in the US Armed Forces, enlisted but not inducted, with certified access to classified information, and separated under honorable conditions, may be naturalized without residency requirements if the application is filed while in service or within six months after separation. A person filing an application for naturalization under specific circumstances related to military service is exempt from certain residency requirements and may be naturalized immediately if currently in the Armed Forces of the United States. The applicant must provide a certified statement from the proper executive department before the final hearing on the application. The applicant must provide a certified statement from the proper executive department showing honorable service, entry through enlistment, and eligibility for classified information access. No fee is charged for filing a naturalization petition or issuing a certificate. The applicant must provide a certified statement showing honorable service, entry through enlistment, and eligibility for classified information access. No fee is charged for filing a naturalization petition or issuing a certificate, which serves as conclusive evidence of service and discharge. Residence, good moral character, attachment to US Constitution principles, and favorable disposition towards the US are required for applicants with non-continuous service within five years. The applicant must prove periods of service in the Armed Forces within five years before filing the naturalization application. Compliance with residency and physical presence requirements is necessary if service ended more than six months before filing. Service under honorable conditions is also required. The curr_chunk discusses the authentication of service records for naturalization of members of the Armed Forces. It also mentions the conduct of naturalization proceedings overseas by the Attorney General, Secretary of State, and Secretary of Defense. Naturalization procedures for Armed Forces members are available at US embassies, consulates, and military installations overseas.
